metadata.case_name: Appellant (Secretary of Nari Kalyan Ashram) v. State of West Bengal

facts.text: Appellant was honorary secretary of Nari Kalyan Ashram in Calcutta, an institution for young girls and women without homes or who had gone astray.
Appellant visited Ashram daily around 7 p.m. till midnight or later, occupied office room with bed-stead, requisitioned girls to massage him.
Between January and April 1954, appellant allegedly committed rape on girls including Sudharani, Narmaya, Kalyani.
On night of April 20, 1954, appellant called Narmaya first, then Sudharani to his room, committed rape on both sequentially using rubber sheath, paid each 8 annas, warned not to disclose.
Sudharani Roy aged about 14-15 years; medical evidence (X-ray ossification on May 19, 1954) estimated 13-14 years.
Narmaya aged above 16 per jury; medical test 15-16 years.

On April 29, 1954, at 10 p.m., Maniktala PS OC and SI visited Ashram re escape of girls; Narmaya and Sudharani alleged rape, pointed to steel locker in secretary's room containing rubber sheath in leather bag.
Woman employee stated appellant asked her to keep rubber sheaths, buried underground, recovered by police.
Kalyani (P.W.19), deaf-dumb, feeble-minded inmate, corroborated via signs interpreted by school principal.
Girls complained to Assistant Secretary Tarun Kumar Sarkar next day.
Defence: Case false, concocted by police, inmates, Assistant Secretary.
Prosecution examined 23 witnesses; no defence evidence beyond cross-examination.

Trial: Additional Sessions Judge, Alipore, Trial No.1 Jan Sessions 1955; jury unanimous guilty on rape of Sudharani u/s 376 IPC, not guilty on Narmaya ('with consent and above 16'). Judge accepted, sentenced 5 years RI.
Calcutta HC Division Bench summarily dismissed appeal (Criminal Appeal No.40/1955) without reasons.
Another Bench (Chakravarty CJ, Lahiri J) examined records, granted certificate u/Art.134(1)(c) on March 18, 1955, despite no arguable points, for appearance of justice.

legal_issues.text: Whether certificate granted by Calcutta High Court u/Art.134(1)(c) is valid, or bad on face as critiquing another bench's summary dismissal.
Whether trial judge erred in refusing to read appellant's written statement to jury.
Whether misdirection on corroboration of victims' testimony, treating them as accomplices.
Whether direction on age of Sudharani incomplete.

petitioner_arguments.text: Certificate invalid as one bench cannot judge another's summary dismissal; observations condemn practice of summary dismissal.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art.134(1)(c) Constitution; Haripada Dey v. State of West Bengal

petitioner_arguments.text: Trial judge refused permission to read written statement filed at Sessions stage.
Serious misdirection on corroboration, treating victims as accomplices.
Direction on age of Sudharani incomplete; police inquiry hearsay.
Case concocted by police, inmates, Assistant Secretary; contradictions/omissions in evidence.

respondent_arguments.text: Preliminary objection: Certificate bad on face, as judgment critiques another bench's dismissal.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Art.134(1)(c); practice of summary dismissal sanctioned by CrPC

court_reasoning.text: Certificate invalid; one bench cannot judge another; observations undermine summary dismissal practice upheld by law; not fit case u/Art.134(1)(c), no complexities of law.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Certifying is strong word; error to grant on facts alone.

court_reasoning.text: No provision in CrPC for written statement at Sessions stage like in magistrates; inadmissible before jury to avoid irrelevancies.

Charge correctly warned on corroboration as prudence (victims not accomplices but prosecutrix evidence needs it); jury can convict on uncorroborated if satisfied; here circumstantial evidence including Kalyani.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Error favoured accused by calling accomplices; Rameshwar v. State of Rajasthan: no rule of law requiring corroboration.

court_reasoning.text: Charge fair on age: considered register, ossification (13-14 yrs), other factors; no birth cert available; inquiry hearsay common.
Charge fair, full, verbose; no merit in appeal even if special leave considered u/Art.136.

holdings.text: Certificate u/Art.134(1)(c) invalid; preliminary objection upheld.
No error in refusing written statement to jury.
No misdirection on corroboration; prudence not compulsion.

precedents_cited.case_name: Haripada Dey v. The State of West Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: Certificate cannot be granted on mere facts; must involve law complexities.

precedents_cited.case_name: Rameshwar v. The State of Rajasthan
precedents_cited.relevance: Corroboration of prosecutrix is rule of prudence, not law; varies by case.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Charge of rape on girls under 16.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Statement u/s.342; no provision for written statement at Sessions like magistrates.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for appeal to SC; special leave.

outcome.summary: Preliminary objection upheld, certificate invalid; on merits, no substance in contentions, trial judge's charge fair, jury verdict upheld; appeal lacks merit.

key_quotes.text: "We are oppressed by the feeling that there were arguable points, although they might not bear examination and the accused has not had the satisfaction of feeling that he has been fully heard by the Court of appeal."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Reason given by HC CJ for granting certificate, held improper by SC.

key_quotes.text: "The only rule of law is that this rule of prudence must be present to the mind of the judge or the jury... There is no rule of practice that there must, in every case, be corroboration before a conviction can be allowed to stand."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Rameshwar, clarifying corroboration for rape prosecutrix.

key_quotes.text: "In our opinion, there is no merit in the appeal."
key_quotes.speaker: court
